updated/revised 26 Aug. 2024 (see Revision History)

5,282 genera

333 subgenera

37,026 species

479 subspecies

43,120 TOTAL FISH NAME ETYMOLOGIES

The ETYFish Project provides name etymologies for every valid genus and species of Recent fish and fish-like vertebrate (plus select subgenera and subspecies in use by some ichthyologists). Names of new taxa and revalidated older names are continually being added.

At present, The ETYFish Project is undergoing a top-to-bottom revision. Each entry is being checked for accuracy and being revised to include more robust etymologies of Latin and Greek words. Plus, newly revised etymologies are easily searched via a database.

This Table of Contents is divided into two parts. Part 1 links to HTML pages of newly revised etymologies; each page has a PDF option with illustrations and in many cases additional information not included in the HTML page. Part 2 comprises links to legacy HTML pages (with PDF options). Revisions will proceed in the phylogenetic sequence as shown below. Over time, Part 1 will get longer and Part 2 will get shorter until all entries have been reviewed and revised.

Infraclass EUSELACHII

eu– (Gr.), good, well or very; selachos (Gr.), a cartilaginous fish, including all elasmobranchs that have an anal fin (secondarily lost in many Recent forms) and two dorsal fins each with an anterior, cylindroconical spine of enameloid and dentine supported by the fin skeleton (spines lost in most living neoselachians; the first dorsal fin is absent in a few living sharks, and one or both dorsals are absent in many rays)

Division NEOSELACHII

neo-, from neos (Gr.), new or modern; selachos (Gr.), a cartilaginous fish, including all Recent sharks and rays and certain Mesozoic sharks, including palaeospinacids (Palaeospinax and Synechodus) and possibly orthacodonts and anacoracids
